comments.content: It's a free game. and for a free game it has given more than most of the recent triple A games. The best part is, you can only buy cosmetics. Your equipment, weapons and armors are all farmable (and can never be bought by real money). That for me is a great game. Chill and fun.

Best thing about Once Human is that developers are actually listening and improving the game. We already had many patches where they fixed, improved or removed certain aspects that players complained about. They also recently had an interview with Pirate Software and what came out of it seems promising. Its too early to dismiss this game based on what Jake said.
Been playing this game and not once did I felt forced or motivated to buy anything from the store. Which is a plus. It's just fun to take your time. Loot and explore and just goof around.

After 150 hours. It's very beautiful, the sound atmosphere is excellent, the pets are fun. The game is very complicated, the quest management interface is poorly explained. In fact, it's not an MMORPG, you don't meet another player every day, there is a reset at the end of each season that makes you lose your house, money, map and discovered areas and you have to start all over again while keeping your weapons. To this day I still haven't been able to upgrade one, too complicated and very difficult. The lifespan seems 200 hours unless you like going around in circles.
Once again, another survival game that draws me in by looking cool just to remind me I suck at survival games

I’m really enjoying this game; it has a chill vibe. Although I’m not usually into survival games, this one has hooked me. The live service elements don’t matter much to me, but the gameplay is simple and engaging. Maybe I'm in the minority, but I always appreciate hearing your views

I'm 20 hours in and it's been awesome. I don't feel like buying anything has been pushed on me, i didn't even know there was a store and battle pass until almost 10 hours in. Building is fun- there's even premade blueprints for houses that are free and you can move your base as you progress to be near higher level raw materials or lake front or in the woods. wherever you want. I got the wish machine early and got luck and drew a purple level assault rifle that wrecks everything but even still gun play is great the way you can stay in 3rd person or move into the scoped view for precision. They've added more servers that are hard levels and more pvp, added dlss support. constant updates and fixes- they're actually listening to the community.
The devs honestly deserve our patience they are great and trying their best

Game is more like Secret World meets Remnant, and a lot of H.P. Lovecraft atmosphere. and you DO NOT need to pay a dime for anything, it is not needed. My friends and I have been playing since launch fully free and nothing is paywalled. it's only cosmetics.
I really appreciated that you mentioned how this game just feels a bit "soulless". That level of honesty is what we need more of today so thank you for that.

20hrs in, not bad for live service. they usually cannot hold my attention this long. building is fun, but can be finnicky at times, story is compelling, bosses are cool, map is huge. idk how long it will last but i'm into it way more than i was the first descendant.
just fyi for everyone using the quote, the full version is: "A jack of all trades is a master of none, but oftentimes is better than a master of one"
Human? i was human once. they didnt put me in a room a perfectly normal room

if its a F2P, and the model is done well. meaning no pressure with shops etc etc, just lets you play accumulated premium currency, has events and stuff than it could be a good model. I mean Genshin is an example where they introduce you to the mechanic, than they leave you be. Its up to you to go to the wish shop.

Jake those multiple currencies are almost all free currencies you get from progression. Only one of them is premium. The others are things you get for doing stuff, like questing, salvaging stuff, etc. True, there's like way too many "store" and other currency pages, and it's pretty confusing to look at, but you can't buy most of the stuff in them with real money. Only one actual store takes real currency, and again, it's mostly cosmetics. The battle pass is $9.99 and is only cosmetics and a few consumables and currencies that you can get in the game anyway. I'd say the more important reason to get the battle pass is to support the devs. The free battle pass is pretty generous.

Been playing this game for 4 days with friends got 26 hours on it so far and i have been enjoying it. You dont need to spend any money just play the game and have fun. For a free game this is alot better then most of the games out there

I’ve been playing the game for around 8 hours and I’ve thoroughly enjoyed it with all the stuff you can do between exploring and boss battles and all the little activities you can do. I think a lot of people forget too and something you didn’t mention is the pvp aspect as well. There will be base raiding and player combat as well which is gonna be sick if they do it right because imagine you and your group are fighting a boss and outta no where another group pulls up to try and ambush you to take your loot etc. I like high risk games like that with that survival aspect
You could always go with "before you try" instead of "before you buy"

I'm 7 hours in and the world doesn't feel boring to me at all, there's always stuff to do, there is a ton of voice acting for a free to play game and the monetization is done well. Even if it suddenly gets boring after awhile in the future, it didn't cost me anything. I think it's worth playing. It's also easy to find people to talk to and play with which, in my experience is not very common these days in online games.
Enemies and environments look good considering the type of game it is usually is empty

I've been having a lot of fun with it. I've really been enjoying the building most. The combat is easy, killing lvl 20-25 when I was a lvl 10. So far that would be my only complaint. Only because it's free to play.

7:00 That is because Net Ease is known for doing exactly that. In fact, I have played several of their mobile games, which are actually really good for mobile games, but they are all this same gameplay loop with different stories, skins and characters. I just started my playthrough of this game, and I immediately recognized everything mechanically because it's exactly what you said it feels like.
Awesome of you guys to upload in ultrawide! Super cinematic. Looks great on a phone and I hardly ever get to use 100% of my desktop display

Devs addressed and improved major feature one day after i submitted survey feedback Filled out a survey in game, checked boxes negatively on the experience of vehicles in game. They then give you a option on the next page to detail your issues, so i explain how the handling is dogsht and it'd be so much funner traversing if it was better. Not only did they massively improve the handling, but they also added improved biking animations which i thought was an awesome touch. GG devs

First time i have to disagree with Jake. This game is Early Access, and was marketed as such, except not on the Steam page for some reason. I get what Jake is saying, but even in Early Access, Once Human is the most fun i've had both solo and with friends. The survival aspect is good, the storyline is linear, but there's no need to follow it if you don't want to. The building and customization are great. Thge atmosphere changes in a very natural way so you get a bit of everything. Wanna go out on a cleaning spree? You can. Wanna get underground, explore deep storylines and fight bosses? You can. Wanna get a nice view of the land while fishing in a lake with the sun on your face? YOU CAN. Once Human speaks to many players in different ways, and that's exceptional in it's own. You can spend money on cosmetics and ''looking cool'', but for the real experience you HAVE to grind. Once Human is a great survival game for both beginners in the genre and experienced players, and with it still being in Early Access, this game has huge potential.
10:49 I mean, you could just rename these videos to "Before You Try" when they're free, instead of commenting on the guff you receive.
"This feels like a PUBG asset flip" - as a train with arms and legs appears.
I was excited for this, was surprised by First Descendant, got hooked onto First Descendant, downloaded Once Human, haven't gone back. But kind of neat you and Falcon split the work load.

This might be the first time I disagree with Jake, I am actually enjoying this game a lot, in the 3 days that I have been playing it, I already lost the track of time twice (it would have been three times was it not for my wife jaja) and that has not happen to me with any game, in a very long time. Sure there are microtransactions, and season pass and all the GaaS crap, but without any of that, you can still get actually pretty good loot, and I personally don't feel the game to be too grindy, for example, every resource node gives you a pretty decent amount of resources, and even more with upgraded tools (unlike Subsistence where you need to chop 1M trees for a foundation and two walls). Is not flawless in anyway, it can be a bit janky, buggy and what not, but I have not had any single game breaking experience (aside from a few T-Posing or sliding character, which some times happens in online games, so is not that bad). I do agree with jake, in that there is a lot of lore and background story and what not, but I am not that into that, so personally i am not affected by that. I love that I can play PvE, which means I don't have to worry about random players ruining the experience for me. The game does have a ton of content, and that is both good and bad, good because there is a toon of stuff and exploration bad because it can be a bit overwhelming.
5:50 Mini-Gun gets you 75 HP. Pulls out a silenced pistol at long range and gets you 160 HP
At 9 min. 48 sec., that is one well built truck to withstand a massive minigun!

I don't agree with few points mentioned in this review, I enjoyed playing this game to level 21 solo without spending any money, most games lack this kind of creating, leveling, looting. I was very surprised that this game had few features that's lacking in recent most games, specially on building/moving house. At the moment I am exploring and doing main story, not much of a story but content is great. But I do wounder what's next once I am done exploring whole map and story. I find this game way better than first descendant on leveling, exploring and grinding.

Ive played this game, I have enjoyed it a lot, as a triple AAA title player, this one feels peaceful even refreshing. Im new to MNK and its also good practice, it reminds me of The Division 2 and The last of us met in a MMO!
Thank you Manscaped for sponosring this video. Get The Chairman Plus for 20% OFF + Free International Shipping with code SKILLUP at https://manscaped.com/skillup. #ManscapedPartner

For those of you who don't wanna scroll through all the comments, here's a handy synopsis: 85% are whining about the channel not reviewing KCD2 or Monster Hunter; 10% are whining about the game resetting progress showing they didn't bother watching the video before posting; 3% are whining about the game being live service and/or online only and/or free to play and/or Chinese; 1.5% are people who actually watched the video and are commenting about it; and the rest are all the people who posted "first."
The game is jank. You will, without question, exclaim "What the heck game?" more than once. I also have 369 hours, fully cleared 5 scenarios, and don't regret a single minute of it.
This game had the weirdest identity crisis on Steam. First it looked kinda like Control, dark and weird and haunting - and then suddenly it started looking like Fortnite or Cod Warzone.
"For the first 10 or so hours i was unimpressed" geez...i drop games after a couple hours of being unimpressed lol
The visceral reaction I had when he said "but like pickles and peanut butter" ...

I played the game myself, got a decent amount of mileage out of it before putting it down. My biggest warning to everyone is that this game suffers from so much Asian MMO jankiness. If you've played any Korean MMO you know what I mean, it also has that same level of "feature creep" where they just added like a million things to the game and now its confusing as hell to play.
I never in a million years expected to care about this game, but by the end of this review I was legitimately excited to get home and start the download so I could give it a try.

Describes a super cool sounding intro sequence "Needless to say, my first impression was not good at all." I dunno, 90% of these games have an intro where the exposit about how holding left click on a tree gives wood for 10 minutes, this sounds a hell of a lot better than that.
I don't know who told you pickles and peanut butter taste good together, but that person lied

I loved playing while I was leveling up--enjoyed building my base and gathering resources. But eventually the number of currencies and specialized resources became overwhelming and exhausting to deal with.

I've sporadically played about 40ish hours since it release and I am thoroughly impressed with how much they've managed to pack into a FREE game. Of course it has the typical battlepass of every single other live service game, but it also has a free track and 90% of real money purchases are just cosmetics, and really cool looking ones at that. When I first played it I was having ridiculously long sessions on it because it was so much fun, but now I just pop back in when new content gets released or theres a new scenario to try. I wanna say most of my time was base building because its got one of the best systems for that out there. Once again, just give it a try because it costs literally nothing to have a good time in it, especially with friends.

I remember losing my rare, shiny blue festering gel after a deviant container bugged out and support couldn't figure out what happened and just said "sorry we can't find the thingy in our records" after hours of grinding Ravenous Hunter.
Brother really said Mrs. Simpson like he was over for dinner. Cute af. 10/10

I have 128 hours in Once Human. I really like the survival crafting aspect as well as exploration. I built a cool house on a beach. I still haven't been everywhere or "finished" the game. I enjoy just taking my time. The only thing I don't like are the boss battles because I just don't like boss battles. I couldn't really say what the story is because I don't really care. I just enjoy the gameplay and weirdness.
Where on earth did this guy hear Pickles and peanut butter go well together
Dont you ever say that shit about pickles and peanut butter in my presence ever again

I have 600+ plus hours on this game but after the live devstream they made some days prior to xmas mentioning that they were focusing on mobile and only going to release new maps by summer or maybe even September, i completely lost interest. The "new" blood moon thing was boring and uninteresting to me and most of my hive mates as it just added more mobs to kill and new loot that isn't that interesting in the first place. No new enemies or bosses or whatever just the typical rinse and repeat since October, when they released the Way of Winter map, which btw i was already in my 4 th playthrough and was already vomiting this game out of my eye balls. The only thing that kept me going was the great hive (guild) friends i made along the way but ultimately most of us just left due to lack of content, objective from the devs, and constant ridiculous focus on lootboxes and skins that don't even match the post apocaliptic feel of the game.
First impressions werent good? Wtf? That sounds like a fucking masterpiece of an opening. How often do we get something so unique?

Once Human still has this very mobile feeling with its super inconsistent, sometimes very "cheap" visuals. The 6 weeks wipes are a major turn off. But I also did not like Palworld for similar reasons - I may be just the wrong demographic for these kind of games.
Once Human, Twice Shy. It also cracks me up how the word "Moreish" is now firmly in common usage outside the UK.
Misread the title and thought I somehow missed the announcement of a Too Human reboot.

watching this video i dont understand how people said Austin copies Ralph, because in the last videos i saw from him he really has his own unique style to talk. Maybe he leaned in the very beginning more into the way Ralph was speaking, but as of right now he really does his own thing and its really cool.

I hate survival games due to the tedious nature of resource collection and tiering. I love Once Human because it simplifies that to essentially an automated task via Deviants so I can focus on the RPG portions of the game that I prefer while still getting to benefit from the base management/creation parts. I also am a big fan of seasons so like that portion of the game as well, I do wish the seasons were a bit longer, 6 weeks is a bit to short I would prefer 8. The game also is heavily geared towards clans/warbands and rewards collaborative planning of specialties and base building. Also, as noted, the seasonal transition mechanism is probably the best in any arpg with the ability to bring stuff with you (I would only bring the rarest deviants and would instead carry over more practical gear like chainsaws and drills). I have added this game into my rotation of seasonal games and it is a nice palette cleanser from the traditional fantasy arpgs that I play.
The U.I on screen is so cluttered - no doubt, because it's coming to mobile.
I know you liked the game, but damn it's still a really hard sell with elements like: 1. First 10 hours suck 2. Live service elements 3. Ubisoft map layouts and side quests 4. Bad story

This is a game that you play while watching youtube in another tab, very easy low pressure game with beautiful map, fun dungeons, and AMAZING base building (Game only has like a two PvE scenarios that play on a loop)

Thanks for reviewing this, I'd never have considered it otherwise. Theoretically this game is right up my alley - I loved the looter shooter aspects of FO76, I've played every Borderlands game and put hundreds of hours into Valheim. This looks literally exactly like what I'd love so I think I'm obligated to spin it up and see what it has to offer.

Ha, I went to look at my hours after reading post and was like damn 1,099 hours. Still loving the game but at my hour count, I would like some new content. I still play 2-3 days a week but I do find myself jumping around to new games or demos for variety.

This game is fun for some time. But it lacks of dopamine hit. Loot has no meaning because you can't repeair gear and weapons if you dont craft them yourself. To be frank, without the loot on the ground and dopamine hit, there is no meaning of looter shooter. You loot bunch of trash to dismantle and thats it. Chase blueprints.
If you played for 10 hours without being impressed, it's not something I want to waste time on, no matter how much better it gets afterwards. Thanks for the warning.

Played this around a month ago, and somehow it didn't stick with me. Got bored pretty quick after 10+ hours, as well as the world felt like one big chore-fest. It seems like a well-cared game at first, but I don't know, maybe I no longer have any time to waste on live-service or crafting/survival open world games. It's just a huge time sink, and I can't really afford that. I'd rather play single player, story driven RPG's, or games in general. It also feels better knowing that there's an end, so you can just move on to something different.
I was willing to give this game a chance because I like looter shooters but I don't enjoy survival craft games. It didn't do well enough in the looter shooter aspect to keep me going though.

Don't play the gacha-machine. Safe up your currency, press G on it and you can literally buy any item you're interested in that basically denies or kills the RNG. They added that not so long ago its really nice.

I have over 49 hours in the past 4 days, I have blinked and lost time and still feel like I haven't been able to do enough. I am a little obsessed and its been literal years since I've felt this way about a game. Cannot wait to see what the seasons in the future hold.
The part of the privacy policy that got people worried would only apply in mainland China and South Korea where it's legally required to give your ID. it is, in fact, a non-issue

This game is literally the amalgamation of every game mechanic i like into one game, set in a beautiful world. I love it, if this keeps going same way this would be a game i will be playing for a really really long time, and create content for.
If they keep this game updated and fresh, I can see myself playing it for a long time. i love it
I wish state of decay 2 was like this, you have your base and then can be tons of other players on the server that also have their base and your base is transportable so you can be anywhere you want

The electric drills and chainsaws and the mustang makes this game even better. The building is really great and you have alot of freedom and blueprints you can find and YOU CAN FISH!! AND HAVE FISHTANKS and there are a TON of fish and the battlepass is so easy to clear with really good rewards that are worth alot being sold and recipes for food is really great as well as the agriculture feature they have to auto farm your crops. There are a ton of different enemies and they are very unique and the rewards that come from weapon, gear and mystical chests offer great rewards. This game is not greedy and it gives out alot of great rewards and you never feel like youre behind a paywall. Sureee the voice acting is missing on most characters but there is so much lore to learn and journals to find. This game is very well refined and excited to see what happens going forward.
The only complaint I have is that my female character will never look hotter than she did in the Test Subject armor.

They need a hotkey to toggle the visibility of whispers. Annoying when people place their whispers PRECISELY on the spot you need to interact with to obtain items or loot, such as the motorcycle. Took me a hot minute to collect my motorcycle due to a troll whisper. I am aware you can block a whisper if you open it, but it would just be more convenient to have an option to toggle them instead of opening them, then blocking them individually in my opinion. Also wholeheartedly agree with the hatred of the 8 separate rewards menus. It's very overwhelming and absurd. But the game is fun. I loooove looter shooters

A note about the server resets/wipes, The devs have been reaching out to content creators & had meetings with some of them to discuss feedback on the game and most have suggested to make changes to the wipes and apparently the devs are looking into possible changes to make the wipes better in some way. Also currently when you buy cosmetics they are locked to your character so if you swap servers you would have to re buy your cosmetics. Well based on feedback the devs have already announced they are changing it so your cosmetics apply to your account on all servers/characters which proves they are willing to make changes based on feedback even if it is going to effect there income in a bad way.

This game has a LOT to do. From being a farmer and selling loot to the vendors, to being a crafter and selling loot in vending machines to other players, creating a base that ACTUALLY looks like a house, with some of the best decorations ive seen in a survival game. Its got Fallout 76 style pvp that wont hold your hand the way F76 did. Its got a V Rising style loot table when youre exploring the world, its got deviations that serve as "pals" for you and your base. Warband faction raiding. Workshop defence, territory control. Im pretty sure I've barely scratched the surface too. With it coming to mobile soon, it's effectively going to be a 4X Survival MMO, the likes of which doesn't really exist in the market today. If Fallout 76, The Division, and ESO had a baby, it would be this. Once Human has infinite possibilities.
This is how you build a game at launch. It's a great game!
Me and 5 of my friends are having a blast. Its just goof fun. Some of the puzzles got my rolling. My buddy got trapped in the hospital for a hr by the living wheel chair.

From what a read on their discord is that each seasons will be a different "scenario" with different world events and things happening. They have 2 full seasons ready (2x6 weeks) and planning on adding more.
Secret world is one of my favorite mmo experiences. Not the best game but the setting / armosphere were just better than anything i have played since. This game gives me that vibe though.
At least the Wish machine isn't just RNG now, you can save up for a specific blueprint if you want.
Ive got 24 hours in the game over the last three days, and you just dropped so much more i didnt even know about yet. There's an insane amount of content in this game, and its free?!?!
I have only been playing about a week, and this is the first survival game I have tried that I have played longer than 15 minutes. It's fun.

NOTE: The Starceom Arcade also has another function where you can press "G" as shown in the video at 23:22. This allows you to directly buy the blueprints vs trying to get a lucky roll. This is more expensive to buy per blueprint but it takes the guess work out of what you want from the drops.
I just love your reviews. Thank you. And may you have many more hours of fun in the game!
The biggest positive I take from this review is that Force went 22 minutes in the video without even mentioning the shop.

The Gaming Merchant also has a video clearly explaining and comparing the privacy policy from other games, disproving all the incorrect assumptions. Once Human also had a livestream addressing and clarifying the issue. I suggest you guys watching them. TLDR: Once Human's privacy policy is no different than most, if not all, other games we play. Great video, Force! Have been enjoying the game too and will put in more hours, for sure.
Absolutely BRILLIANT! review of Once Human. Thank you so much for your wealth of information. I'm also enjoying this game a lot.
Force, go up to the wish machine and press G, you can buy the blueprints outright. you do not have to gamble for them.

I've spent about 55 hours since launch, completed every task, every objective and zones/towns there is to offer in phase 1. Level 65 battlepass. Level 39 character. Spent about 25h building! Now i just wait for phase 2 to start. Having a blast with some of my buddies. Love the game!
You can purchase the blueprints directly from the Wish machine now, which I don't recall being an option in the beta tests.

This review is absolutely wonderful and talks about literally everything you can imagine..... besides Eternaland, what it is, how it works and more importantly how that plays into the reset. Did you forgot this or what went wrong here? :D Honestly, the reset isn't even a real issue. And here is why. The list below is everything you'll keep, regardless of seasons and servers switching up: Important Currency: Starchroms, Crystgins, Mitsuko's Marks, Stellar Planula, and Sproutlets Gear Blueprints (and their stars), Blueprint Fragments, Weapon Accessories, and Mods Furniture Formulas (except those gained through your Memetics) Cosmetics, Expressions and Poses, Namecards, and more House Blueprints. After a House Blueprint is saved, you can reconstruct the building at any time (if advanced materials are not available, basic materials will be used in building instead) Main story and side story task progress (for the tasks you've already completed, you can accept more streamlined versions of them in the new season but still get all the rewards) Your friend list will fully carry over. Furthermore, you can check which players joined your Warband in the previous seasons and add them to your friend list The list below is content that is "partially carried over" into a new Once Human season: Essential resources like materials, medicine, and ammunition can be carried over into a new season based on item transferring rules so you can progress faster in the new season And besides all that, you have your Eternaland where nothing get's ever reset and you can most of your stuff in there and partly even out again for the next season. People just hear "reset" and go nuts instead of trying to understand that it isn't really a "reset" after all.

Thanks so much for a great real gameplay review. I have been enjoying the game as well and have also been wondering what am I going to do when I reach the end or the season ends. I really play games for two reasons. Play with friends and enjoy the story. I would love to see a video on what we spend our resources on when either of these two events occurs.

All is fun and games till you unlock the JAWS! Little tip with semi weapons; Change your settings so it will auto fire so your DPS will increase! Jelly is god tier deviation. You do not need another source of heal or sanity restore till end of the game!

as someone who recently discovered this game, i really appreciate that developers are going for something different. this is not just some ordinary online game, the atmosphere is catchy, the ideas are nice and innovative , the exploration is nice and entertaining . you CAN actually design your own character from head to toe in details! you can build your base, and establish facilities that are functional and exploitable! yeah the game is laggy, there are bugs, but this is something they can WORK on!!! i am really happy i discovered this game , and im rooting for it. hopefully owners listen to the fans and keep optimizing / expanding the game, cause i truly see this game has BIG potential. may it become one of the mainstream online games one day.
I LOVE the animations for everything. That’s what made me love every detail in this game
I swear every time a game comes out Force uploads a vid like 2 days after release "I've played 300 h of X - Review". You're living the dream.

Biggest issue this game has for me is how easy and often times brain dead feeling the enemies are, a lot of the more regular enemies feel like they have little to no AI other then periodically waking up and trying to hit you. The zombie like creatures are the biggest offense to this, they aren't a threat at all.

I'm having a blast with this game. It has the MMO or Ubisoft highly repetitive nature where you go from outpost to outpost and do all the same things over and over (activate rift beacon, find mystical crate, find 1 or 2 gear crates, kill 15 enemies, kill an elite enemy, lather, rinse, repeat) but the tedium of the repetition is softened by the fact that the moment to moment gameplay is quite good. The gunplay is good, the guns feel varied and properly punchy, the feedback is great, as is the sound design. What really surprised me is how good melee felt in this gun-focused game; it is floaty, but it feels really good to me. I particularly like the shoulder charge move. It also helps that this game has some great creature designs, both in terms of the visuals and the way the creatures attack/behave.
Well the game was definitely a breath of fresh air in the industry.

You can adjust the height of your houses foundation when moving ur house around..so the terrain shouldn't be a problem. You can also unlock blueprints & bp fragments with the wish machine, that u unlock in the memetics screen...which uses starchrom. Starchrom or "unrefined starchrom" can be found, in chests, doing quests, dungeon runs, farming bosses and using the resonator.
It doesn't help 90% of the cutscenes are hit or miss if they will be voiced or not.. makes it feel like a rushed beta. Also did the reviewers not play the game you can craft from storage...
I don't know why but sometimes the interaction options don't show up for story mission. Like when I approach an NPC there is no talk option.

I really don't know where the negativity from this game is coming from. Yes, the voices sometimes dissapear while talking with a npc. Yes, there are a few little bugs in the game. But overall, everything feels good in this game. Movement, shooting, switching to and from build mode and the game is also balanced in the fact of grinding essential stuf. This game is better then most triple A game studios. It works perfectly. It has all the good things from games like: the division, rust,ark,destiny and open world maps like skyrim, fallout etc. Oh, and the best thing is, it's free. Just play it and give it your own opionion instead of listing to these kind of video's that is not even correct. I give this game a 7.5/10 for now. With alot of potential.
I like the game but the fact that your character vaults without pushing any button is criminal. I fall off so many times because if you run towards railing you will vault it
For me the game is okay. One thing I dont' like is there isn't much a sense of danger. You can just go around stomping mobs that barely fight back unless its a boss or something. Just feels bland.

Okay. Journalism needs to change in gaming. It’s affecting the community. There’s way too many followers in the gaming community. Way too many people who do not have their own brains or opinions. For this weirdo to say you cannot craft from storage is insane. We need people apart of these blogs to be actual GAMERS and play games so they can be reviewed correctly and put out false Information
I don’t know if it’s a feature but I log off yesterday and logged on today to find my deviants with very full inventories, like 2000 wood and a ton of minerals Made enough charcoal for the day

Once human en pc, si es cierto que a diferencia de muchos otros juegos no se siente tanto como jugar en emulador de android, pero digamos que le quedan esos residuos de interfaz sobre todo, tiene esos residuos de las intenciones en la interfaz, digamos que el juego fue pensado primero para mobiles y toda la interfaz del juego esta hecha pensando en mobiles, eso explicaría por que el inventario no es una simple ventana si no en cambio es a pantalla completa, y tambien explica por que el chat es tambien a mitad de pantalla, esto se hace para que las opciones estén en las esquinas de la pantalla, y en mobile sea mucho mas cómodo ya que la pantalla de un celular es mucho mas pequeña y los dedos generalmente siempre quedan cerca de los bordes de la pantalla, entonces gran parte de toda la interfaz de once human en pc es: menús a pantalla completa donde las opciones y demás pestañas están cerca de los bordes de la pantalla, o sea la intencion en la interfaz de hacer que las opciones de los menu queden siempre en el borde de la pantalla sea arriba o abajo o a un lado hace que se sienta la intención de que fue hecho pensado para mobiles, en un juego de pc, el inventario por ejemplo seria una pequeña ventana y no apantalla completa, pero no es algo que se note muy al principio con el tiempo es que uno se da cuenta que a esa interfaz le faltan muchos cambios en pc

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION FOR NEW OR RETURNING PLAYERS FROM A 1500 HOUR PLAYER!! As this is a sponsored video, Force cannot give the list of cons that he normally does so I'll give you a quick list here. - Keyword effects are still broken. They work around 30% of the time so you lose 90% of your damage in open world events. - The scenario is hard difficulty, so even the first enemies you come across are insanely strong. - Levels for areas have been changed too so farming specific resources requires going to different areas than you would have in previous scenarios. - There are no Prime Wars or Thermal Towers. - They added scaling for the Nightmare Tubes, the more players, the more ridiculous the HP of the boss. - Dream Zones need to be cleared before you can build a base in the location and the Dream Zone respawn after X amount of time. - You cannot enter Silos or Monoliths if a Dream Zone is active on them. You need to clear the Dreamer every single time they respawn in order to run them. Super dumb. - You cannot teleport to a location that is inside a Dream Zone, so if you put a camp down and a Dream Zone spawns on it, you can't teleport to it anymore. I think they are changing that on July 2nd though. - They added permanent servers. To get to them, select a Scenario and wait until the scenario ends, at which point you get moved to the permanent version automatically. However, permanent servers do not get new content (apart from Visional Wheel stuff but those are events, not real content). - The priorities of the devs is STILL very much gacha loot crates. The newest loot crate even has an entire building set in it so it's not just character cosmetics anymore and it would cost around $300-400 to get that building set from the gacha. Ultimately, in case my time played wasn't enough of an indicator, I think Once Human might be the best MMO on the market at the moment AND it's free. However, it has a ridiculous amount of issues that devs are just not interested in fixing because loot crates are making them so much money.

My thing is that the reviews are misinformation. An official statement reads "where the local laws require us to do so (such as for a specific promotion), when the identity of a user’s parent must be verified to obtain consent for their child (if required by applicable child protection laws), or when the user wishes to correct their age information (again, if such verification is required by law). In any case, the ID information is deleted immediately after we have fulfilled the purpose for collecting the ID information in the first place." It's not collected in the US, but other countries looking to play and have strict identity laws. As a software developer who has built drivers and user applications across windows and linux systems.. Everything their driver can obtain in kernel mode can also be obtained in usermode also. (usermode is you and myself, just launching an app, that's usermode) The primary and watered down difference between user and kernel mode is that kernel mode you can read and write any type of data you want, usermode you can essentially do the same, but more limited.. kernel gives you 100% read / write access, usermode gives you like 95% read / write access,.. and the small amount you can't access in usermode is for system and your own security... usermode apps can still get you IP, HWID information, account SID, email, etc...

key_facts_from_comments: FACT: Once Human is a free-to-play game with no pay-to-win mechanics; all equipment, weapons, and armor are farmable and cannot be purchased with real money.
FACT: The game features seasonal resets every 6 weeks, during which players lose their house, map progress, and discovered areas but retain gear, blueprints, and key currencies.
FACT: Players can purchase cosmetics and battle pass content using real money, but the battle pass is mostly free and offers generous rewards.
FACT: The developers actively listen to community feedback and have implemented changes based on player surveys and direct input.
FACT: The Wish Machine allows players to directly buy blueprints without relying on random drops, reducing RNG dependency.
FACT: The game's privacy policy has been clarified by the developers and is not unique or more invasive than other major games.
FACT: Players can carry over essential currencies, gear blueprints, friend lists, and story progress across seasons, minimizing the impact of resets.
FACT: The game supports cross-platform play and is being developed for mobile, console, and PC with plans for future releases.
FACT: Players can move their base anywhere on the map using transportable house blueprints, enabling flexible base placement near resources.
FACT: The game includes a variety of gameplay systems such as farming, fishing, crafting, base building, PvP, warband raids, and exploration.
FACT: The game's UI is designed with mobile compatibility in mind, leading to full-screen menus and edge-based controls.
FACT: The game features a wide range of enemy types, including unique creatures inspired by Lovecraftian and SCP-style themes.
FACT: Players can unlock and customize their character’s appearance in great detail, including clothing, accessories, and expressions.
FACT: The game includes a variety of functional buildings and facilities like fish tanks, vending machines, and automated farms.
FACT: The game has received multiple updates improving vehicle handling, animations, and overall performance based on player feedback.
key_opinions_from_comments: OPINION: The seasonal reset system is a major turn-off for many players who prefer persistent progression and long-term investment.
OPINION: The game feels overly repetitive after extended play, with many players describing it as a 'rinse and repeat' loop of tasks.
OPINION: The game’s early hours are underwhelming, but it improves significantly after the first 10–20 hours of gameplay.
OPINION: The game’s monetization model is fair because it only sells cosmetics and does not gate core gameplay behind paywalls.
OPINION: The game’s mobile-first UI design makes it feel awkward on PC, despite its strong gameplay and visuals.
OPINION: The game’s survival mechanics are simplified through automated resource collection via Deviants, making it accessible to non-survival fans.
OPINION: The game’s atmosphere and lore evoke strong comparisons to Secret World, The Division 2, and H.P. Lovecraft-inspired settings.
OPINION: The game’s PvP and base raiding elements add high-risk excitement that enhances the survival experience.
OPINION: The game is a standout among free-to-play titles due to its depth, content, and lack of predatory monetization.
OPINION: The game’s lack of meaningful danger and weak enemy AI diminishes the sense of threat and immersion.
OPINION: The game’s constant updates and developer responsiveness show genuine commitment to long-term success.
OPINION: The game feels like a blend of Fallout 76, Valheim, and Ark, but with better base-building mechanics.
OPINION: The game’s story and voice acting are inconsistent, with many cutscenes lacking proper voiceovers.
OPINION: The game’s visual style shifts between dark, atmospheric tones and bright, cartoonish aesthetics, creating an identity crisis.
OPINION: The game’s success depends on whether developers can maintain fresh content and avoid stagnation post-launch.
key_datapoints_from_comments: DATA: 6-week seasonal resets occur in Once Human, requiring players to rebuild progress each cycle.
DATA: 90% of real-money purchases in the game are limited to cosmetics and non-essential items.
DATA: The battle pass costs $9.99 and includes cosmetics, consumables, and currencies obtainable through gameplay.
DATA: Players report 8–15 hours of gameplay before feeling fully engaged, with some losing interest after 10 hours.
DATA: Some players have logged over 500+ hours in the game, with one reporting 1,099 hours of playtime.
DATA: The game has been played for up to 369 hours by dedicated players without regretting their time investment.
DATA: 20–30 hours of gameplay is considered sufficient by many to form a positive opinion of the game.
DATA: The game features 2 full seasons (each 6 weeks) already planned and ready for release.
DATA: Players can carry over 10+ types of essential currencies, gear blueprints, and friend lists across seasons.
DATA: The Wish Machine allows direct purchase of blueprints, bypassing RNG with a G-key shortcut.
DATA: The game includes over 40 different enemy types, with unique behaviors and attack patterns.
DATA: The game has 10+ different base-building blueprints available from the start, with more unlocked via progression.
DATA: The game supports cross-platform play between PC, mobile, and upcoming console versions.
DATA: The game’s UI uses full-screen menus and edge-based controls, optimized for mobile touchscreens.
DATA: The game’s privacy policy applies only in mainland China and South Korea due to local legal requirements.
major_themes: Theme: Free-to-play monetization model focused solely on cosmetics and non-essential items
Theme: Seasonal resets and progression cycles every 6 weeks
Theme: Base building, customization, and transportable housing mechanics
Theme: Developer responsiveness and community feedback integration
Theme: Mobile-first UI design impacting PC experience
Theme: Repetitive gameplay loops and grind fatigue
Theme: Atmosphere and lore inspired by Lovecraft, SCP, and post-apocalyptic settings
Theme: PvP, warband raids, and player-driven conflict
Theme: Resource management, crafting, and automated gathering via Deviants
Theme: Cross-platform availability and future console/mobile releases
top_engagement_markers: High-engagement comment about seasonal resets: Many players find the 6-week wipe cycle frustrating, though devs are considering improvements based on feedback.
High-engagement comment about monetization: The game is praised for being free-to-play with no pay-to-win mechanics, focusing only on cosmetics.
High-engagement comment about base building: Players highlight the freedom and creativity in designing and moving bases across the map.
High-engagement comment about developer responsiveness: A player shares how vehicle handling was improved within a day of submitting feedback.
High-engagement comment about the Wish Machine: Direct blueprint purchasing via G-key removes RNG frustration and is seen as a major quality-of-life win.
High-engagement comment about game longevity: One player reports 1,099 hours of playtime and still enjoys the game, indicating strong retention.
High-engagement comment about UI design: Multiple users note the mobile-first interface feels clunky on PC, especially with full-screen menus.
High-engagement comment about game identity: The game is compared to Secret World, The Division 2, and Fallout 76, with mixed reactions to its aesthetic shift.
